ygData.subject: Re: Neuron Output Conservation of Enery
ygData.msgSnippet: If we assume that the energy being fed to the network is the magnitude of the inputs, then it becomes clear why such an approach is not applicable in most ANN

If we assume that the energy being fed to the network is the magnitude 
of =
the inputs, then it becomes clear why such an approach is not 
applicable i=
n most ANN models. Any weight above 1.0 will make the 
signal stronger and =
any weight below 1.0 will make it weaker. Weights 
close to 0.0 will make t=
he signal disappear. This is the way ANNs 
ignore information. Suppose you =
have an ANN with all weights set to 0. 
The output you will get may be stat=
ic all the time, but the lack of 
signal doesn't mean there is lack of *inf=
ormation*, since the NN is essentially trained to ignore everything. 
The m=
athematical model that is used to represent artificial neural 
networks doe=
sn't cover conservation of energy or anything like that. 
In fact, why you =
would need such a thing at all? Is there a merit in 
the approach? I am int=
erested.

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Eric Mohlenhoff <eric.mohlenh=
off@...> 
wrote:
>
> From my (probably limited) understanding of neurobiolo=
gy, such a
> conservation of energy principle would not be applicable to th=
e 
model
> of neurons firing. At least not in the sense that I believe you =
are
> describing.
> 
> 'Energy' as it were, is not really 'transferred' bet=
ween any given
> neurons in such a system. Neurons only interact via 
neuro=
transmitters
> being released into and absorbed from the synaptic cleft bet=
ween 
said
> neurons. Electrical energy (which I gather is to what you are
=
> referring) is confined to within a particular neuron itself. In a
> prope=
rly functioning neuron, this energy is neither received nor
> transmitted. =
In fact, (and I may be mistaken here, so somebody 
correct
> me if I am) I =
beleive that the effects of such neurological diseases
> as multiple sclero=
sis are actually precipitated by this electrical
> energy escaping the cell=
 due to a degeneration of the myelin sheath
> that would normally cover the=
 axon of the cell, along which the
> electrical signals within the cell tra=
vel from dendrite to axon
> terminal.
> 
> If it were the case that a conse=
rvation of energy principle was
> applied to such a model, and the electric=
al signals *were* being
> transmitted cell-to-cell, this would impose a cei=
ling on the number 
of
> layers possible in the network, degree of recursio=
n in feedback
> networks, etc. due to what would be inevitable signal degra=
dation to
> the point of no longer being usable. That is unless there was a=
lso 
the
> provision for 'repeater' cells/nodes in the network (a concept t=
hat 
I
> have personally not encountered as of yet).
> 
> Basically, the en=
ergy that is 'distributed' across connecting 
neurons
> actually comes from=
 within the cell (insert complex/detailed
> discussion about mitochondria, =
phosphorylation, etc. here... haha),
> itself being a function of the type,=
 amount, and possibly other
> yet-to-be-discovered properties of the neurot=
ransmitters (and 
possibly
> other chemicals as well) that are within the s=
ynaptic cleft at the
> time that the firing was initiated.
> 
> A better an=
alogy (I believe) would be the one proposed by a large 
body
> of the liter=
ature: a single neuron is a black-box function. It takes 
a
> given input (=
absorbing neurotransmitters from the synaptic cleft) 
and
> produces an out=
put (releasing neurotransmitters into the synaptic
> cleft). Any conservati=
on of energy principle is resetricted to being
> applied to the processes o=
ccurring within the cell itself, because 
in
> this (limited) sense the cel=
l is acting as a closed system for that
> electrical energy.
> 
> Hope this=
 helps,
> 
> Eric
> 
> PS Anyone, feel free to correct me if any of this is=
 off-base or 
just
> plain wrong too. I'm just going by my cursory understa=
nding of these
> things, and so could be mistaken about some of this.
> 
> =

> <rvonwahlde@...> wrot=
e:
> > I have a question relating to the analogy of the interconnected 
nod=
es
> > of an artificial neural net as neurons. A node receives inputs 
that=

> > are fed into an activation function. The activation function 
"fires"
=
> > an output somewhat comparable to a synapse firing. As implemented 
in
>=
 > ANN's, the same output value (its "energy" as it were) from the 
node is=

> > fed through weighted links to other nodes. What would be the 
effect o=
f
> > imposing a sort of "conservation of energy" principal on the ANN?
> >=

> > Isn't it the case that in an actual neural net, when a neuron 
fires i=
ts
> > total energy is distributed somehow to its connecting neurons. The
>=
 > total energy received by the connected neurons can not be more 
than the=

> > energy generated by the sending neuron. What if in an ANN, the 
value
=
> > coming from a node was split evenly between the outgoing links? 
And
> =
> for the receiving nodes, the sum of the weighted inputs could not
> > exc=
eed the total energy generated by the sending nodes. Would 
there be
> > an=
y benefit to forcing this restriction on an ANN?
> >
> >
